LOL.

Did you ever sculpt in 3D ?
The only good thing for 3D is Oculus Medium however:
1) VR for more then 1h is tiresome
2) The computer can be unable to handle this amount of voxels and crap itself (more like this will be ready in 2030 or if hardware accelerates; Not buying new PC because of inflation and tech stagnation)
3) in VR you do not really have a feel for the sculpture only what the shit quality googles show you, you can not imagine how you miss that one.

As for blender it is great for farting out mechanical things like robots and tubs and guns however has a problem with organic shapes. Sure I can replace parts of the Oculus medium sculpts with blender machinery if I'm making a cyborg.

However physical sculpting is a half hobby and a half processional thing for me since I use it to relax and learn the anatomy of a sculpt (this helps me in occulus).

I love to have a 3D scanner for that.
I do not need crazy details since this can be added in post processing.

>Dunno, for me it looks similar to beeswax with few addons, so propably you need more heat than y

How do you process the information in the books?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6410749
I honestly really recommend you downliad his 10 year old seminar, mostly because you get to see him apply the method live which is pretty helpful
I believe they are available in the /video course/ general in /ic/

Here is the homework either way :o


----------------------------------------
Course Description:
As students continue to develop a basic skill set throughout this course, a special emphasis will be placed on the understanding and application of those basics to the human figure. This course will emphasize a process based approach and development of the figure heavy in an analysis of from, construction, and perspective. This course will offer and in depth study of the figure and the surface anatomy while always maintaining a grounding in the artistic and principles of design.
Week 1: Lecture: Introduction of teacher/ Goals of class. Lecture on gesture and the development of a process.

Homework: 100 Gesture Drawings (half should be done from life, the other half from Old Masters drawings, paintings or sculpture). Choose 5 of your best gestures to submit for critique and instructor feedback. Drawings may be scanned in and submitted or submitted as digital files done in photoshop or as jpgs. You may also upload one, or more, for student feedback on the class blog.
Week 2: Lecture: Connections, Shape and Understanding the skeletal landmarks.
Homework: 25 construction drawings. Drawings should follow in class process of gesture, shapes, connections, landmarks, and finally into a development of the perspectives of the torso, arms, and legs. Choose 2-5 of your best to submit for critique and instructor feedback.
Week 3: Lecture: Head Drawing. Construction and design of the human head.
Homework: 25 Head constructions. Following the in class work flow, develop the head from simple shapes into the architectural planes. Development of the features is optional. Choose 2-5 of your best to submit for critique and instructor feedback
----

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6410753
Week 4: Lecture: Muscles: Torso/trunk. Placing the anatomical shapes of the upper and lower torso based off the understanding of the skeletal landmarks.
Homework: 25 Construction drawing with the anatomy of the upper and lower torso included on top. Only develop the muscles covered within the lecture, but be sure to draw the entire pose. Choose 2-5 of your best to submit for critique and instructor feedback.
Week 5: Lecture: Torso 2.
Homework: 25 Construction drawing with the anatomy of the upper and lower torso included on top. Include the muscles discussed in the prior week as well as the anatomy of the torso. Choose 2-5 of your best to submit for critique and instructor feedback.
Week 6: Lecture: Structure and anatomy of the legs
Homework: 25 Leg and pelvis constructions. Include the anatomy on top of the underlying skeletal and perspective breakdowns. Pay close attention to the shape, gesture, and perspective of each shape as you build. Choose 2-5 of your best to submit for critique and instructor feedback.
Week 7: Lecture: The structure, design and anatomy of the upper arm and shoulders.
Homework: 25 Shoulder and arms constructions. Develop the anatomy of the upper arms together with the anatomy of the upper torso. This week should specifically focus on the shoulder girdle and the muscles of the scapula and front of the humerus. Choose 2-5 of your best to submit for critique and instructor feedback.
Week 8: Lecture: The structure, construction, and design of the forearm.
Homework: 25 Shoulder and arms constructions. Develop the anatomy of the upper arms together with the anatomy of the forearms. Choose 2 of your best to submit for critique and instructor feedback.
---------------------

Thats all of it, save it into a notepad or something :o

**Strive for quantity AND quality.**

Anime Studying:
>Copy anime references exactly and draw them from memory. Use illustrations, screenshots, anime figures, 3D models, etc.
>Don’t copy recklessly. Use construction, color theory, and other fundamental concepts to rehearse a drawing process that you can later easily manipulate for original artwork.
>Post all of your anime studies. Post even when you’re told not to. Create an art community that actually draws and improves together instead of just talking about it.
>Number your attempts and link to your previous posts.
>Critiquers should lead by example by posting their studies.

General Anime Style Discussion:
>Questions about achieving certain styles/techniques/compositions etc.
>Drawing methods, study habits, resources, tutorials, tools, software, etc
>Be specific and try to post a sample of your study attempts before asking for help.

Fuck off retard. Ask a better question.

Recommended tablets:

>Intuos 3
Best screenless tablet. Look for one on Craigslist or Ebay.
>Intuos 4, 5 & Pro
Also good options. Will burn through your nibs.
>Samsung Galaxy Tab S6 Lite
Budget portable display tablet. Very solid drawing experience with Wacom EMR tech, but a small 10.4" display area.
>Used iPad Pro 2nd Gen 12.9"
Best option for a display tablet.
>Galaxy Tab S7+/S8+
Good premium alternative to an iPad Pro
>One by Wacom (not Wacom One)
Solid cheap option

Avoid:

>XP-Pen, Huion, Gaomon and every other Chinese brand
Poor build quality, lackluster pens, broken tilt, struggles to register light pressure, horrible customer support and the displays are not calibrated. All Chinese brands have the same problems. Check out the webm to understand how bad they are. Also watch out, Chinese companies shill HARD on /ic/; they do a lot of samefagging and frequently hurl personal insults.

>Microsoft Surface Pro
The N-Trig digitizer means you will always get wobbly lines.

>Lenovo
Bad drawing performance because they're not designed with art in mind.

>iPads (brand new) - Bad value
>iMacs and Macbooks - Never buy this garbage under any circumstance. It's a locked ecosystem with rubbish hardware you can't upgrade.

com:
This thread is dedicated to master studies, where you copy artwork you admire as a form of study. They are the quickest way to improve and learn about any fundamental you are having problems with. If you need to work on your hands, copy hands from other artists, and if you're having trouble with rendering, make careful studies of paintings with lighting you admire. Studies can be quick or long. You can even copy anatomy books like Bridgman, Morpho, and Hogarth. The type of studies you want to do depend on your personal goals and the types of problems you are grappling with.

Artists of all levels are welcome. Critiques and redlines are encouraged.

com: does anyone have any decent tutorials or guides on how best to go from greyscale to color without it looking muddy, flat, and bad? this is my art below and i want to color it but no matter what tutorial i follow, its awful :/

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: AI coloring?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
You will have to paintover a lot.

I like using color blending mode + overlay, having a good reference and desaturating the reference as well so I have a notion of both the correct colors and the correct values.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6407090
The lightest values should be less saturated (more towards white) than the mid tones. In other words, you're missing the reflective highlights

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
There is no one way to automatically get something that works, every method has a downside along with the upsides.
Gradient maps result in banding/artifacts if you overdo them, but they give fine tune control.
Best blend modes are Multiply (will always darken so you'll have to go back in and paint over, but it's good as a starting point if your intention is to manually color later), and Overlay/Hardlight (Overlay risks blowing out the contrast, particularly with very dark or very light colors, and Hardlight destroys contrast with overly light and dark colors).
"Color" blend mode was designed for coloring b/w photographs, so it works well only if you paint your greyscale with the local color values in mind (if thatst he case working directly with color might be better).
In the end you'll always have to eyeball the result and adjust accordingly, including playing with the opacity of any blend mode layers you use. It'll never be as simple as laying in flats by color picking from a reference sheet.

com: Is art school actually worth it? I’ve heard that it’s really only for getting connections into the industry. I want to be able to make art professionally but I want to know how much not going to college would limit me these days.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6404281
Connections are the main thing, but school provides
>structured learning
it tells you what to learn and when. Yes you can find all the resources and books on the internet, but its just way too much for anyone to delve into without guidance. Have a structured form of guidance that tells you what should be learned first and for how long really helps you focus on what's important, rather than say getting trapped up in anatomy for 2 years when you're a /beg/ who can't into a straight line.
>Deadlines and grades
it forces you to get stuff done. The pressure can be good. I have a sub to NMA that just sits there, once a week i'll watch a video or something but i just have no pressure to work on anything in specific so i'll often to regress to doing whatevers comfortable. anime waifus.
>Actual coaching and mentoring
while instructors are hit or miss, if you actively go to them for help most of them are willing to help you out, give you guidance, and give you actual critiques. its not something you can easily get elsewhere and /ic/ is not a valid replacement for an actual rpofessional pointing out your problems and giving you advice.

Its probably not worth 100k or whatever it costs. but considering how much degrees are pushed on people now days, if its what you want to do you could be wasting money in worse ways. And at worst you still get the school connections.

com:
Post your favorite / least favorite books on art / art instruction / art history and why you like it / hate it.

>Vilppu Drawing Manual.
This book, along with a perspective and anatomy book, is literally all you need to make it. It gives you the foundation of 3 dimensional drawing, facility for drawing and painting from imagination, and the tools you need to learn anything else, preparing you for a fruitful career in art. The exercises are progressive, they go very deep, and there's no end to the mastery of any of it. Plus, there is no fluff, focusing only on the fundamentals, and it never wastes your time.

>Bridgman
Copy through his books twice! There's no better way to learn to draw the human figure. His constructions are perfectly for Michelangelo-ish type characters and give you the knowledge you need to invent figures from any angle, from imagination. This works perfectly with Vilppu.

>David Chelsea's Comic Book perspective
It's a basic perspective rulebook, but the best thing is that he gives you "shortcuts" to lay out your perspective so you can work efficiently, because this book is tailored towards comic book artists who have tight deadlines but still need to build environments from imagination. This book covers everything you need for perspective.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6409681
I can only speak for Procreate and Krita (and GIMP to a lesser extent) at the moment, but the smudge/blend tool is not going to give you the results you want. I almost never use it. Especially when I'm just practicing values. Now...if you have environment light and you want to blend that in with your subject's flats, the smudge/blend tool DOES have some utility there.

To get that kind of shading in the black area, you only need the airbrush tool. Consider sitting down and experimenting with the brush engine in your software of choice. Maybe watch some people online using real airbrushes for ideas? The settings should be fairly self explanatory. Ever seen those guys that make t-shirts at the mall and fairs/circus? H.R. Giger is an example of a famous artist who used airbrush. (You're studying art history, right?!) I can't emphasize the importance of learning how to airbrush if you want really soft shadows/gradients/whatever.

1/2

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6409699
Masks. Well, the trad analogy is literally masking tape. But you can also think of it as a stencil. For example, a stencil made from cardboard or a plastic sheet. The paint/pixels only affect the part of the canvas that isn't covered by the mask. If you're patient, I can answer any questions you have until you understand it. Just check back a few times a day and take your time. Also, don't expect it to "click" instantly. It doesn't mean you're stupid. You just need to have that "eureka!" moment.

But more broadly, masks help you to "color inside the lines" without having to actually respect/obey the boundaries. Here's an example: sketch the first letter of your first name as a "bubble letter". Like an animal balloon. You can just use the Procreate Pencil brush, for example. Now create a new layer and ink over your pencil sketch very carefully. Don't expect instant results. Take your time and work on a new layer. Now...underneath that layer, create a new layer and carefully fill it in to create a silhouette. At this stage you WILL need to worry about coloring inside the lines, but just this once. Now lock the alpha pixels of that layer and select your airbrush. (And duplicate the layer and disable it so you have a backup copy.) Don't worry about masks for now. We'll get there. Alpha lock is basically the same thing. Masks are less destructive and the better tool, but you're trying to just understand the basic concept. Any pixel that is alpha (i.e. transparent) will not accept color from the brush. So anything outside of your silhouette/fill color will not be affected by the brush.

2/2

last_replies.com:
Its mostly a meme op. It only really matters if the subject is very pale or under a neutral or cool light. Otherwise most skin tones are too saturated to matter BUT where it does come into play is in hue shifts so if you want to add interest in your portraits those are the hues you can safely gravitate towards. Just remember color is relative do it won't be Blue or green it will be just grey versions of orange or red that look blue and green next to more saturated planes. You can reliably throw in grey's in the receding planes of people's faces it gives the illusion of depth like the sides of the nose or the temples.

This is a portrait I painted a few years ago for a friend, if you notice the face is basically red with little variation in major hue shifts but if you look your can see greens I added. In my opinion those are more important than the meme image in the op everyone references. The big factor in those cool shifts are background color. There's so many variables that go into color, I wouldn't even worry about it. Values and likeness are immensely more important you can get away with color going purely on feel and instinct until you develop a feel for what's right. I hope this helped

>>6403508
I think it has something to do with how your brain translates drawings into "brain data" and basically overlooks flaws and accounts for artstyle ,when your eyes send signals to your brain , it forms an image , but that alone is of no use , the image needs to be interpreted somehow , so when it sees , an eye , anime figure , real person , a lion , whatever the fuck:
"This is supposed to be an eye , pink , medium sized"
"This is supposed to be a person , female , medium-to-large sized hips , large breasts, hourglass bodytype , next to no skin imperfections , relatively muscular"
"This is a lion cub"

This "artstyle translation" tends to crash and burn when you attempt to bring anime to real life. Then it looks uncanny because your brain no longer accounts for artstyle. For example in anime you sometimes dont draw the mouth , while your brain doesnt mind this in anime (it just fills in the gaps) , if someone where to not have a mouth at all or have their mouth dissapear from certain angles for some reason , you would be terrified.

So why does anime work better than other artstyles at this...I think its because:
1. Your brain is used to making the "artstyle translation" due to you watching anime.
2. anime figures usually dont have many if any imperfections so when your brain "processes" the images it doesnt add any or at the very least , not that many.
3. Its usually more realistic (depends on style but thats why I say usually) , atleast compared to cartoons that tend to be straight up caricatures. Shading might be a bit simplistic , but your brain can fill in the blanks on that.

Hell , I heard some people basically just draw a realistic/semi-realistic person , simplify the shading and use lines to depict certain things, remove some imperfections (eg. Cellulite, acne , etc.) , draw an anime face on the figure and then call it anime.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
The only "masteries" are

>line quality

>Perspective

>Anatomy

>Values


Line quality is the best to learn first, deciding what's thick and what's thin, using lines to imply the shape instead of perfectly tracing it out. Anatomy is next, its just measurements. The head is as complex as the entire body, but the key is consistency. Perspective is being able to rotate what you drew and draw it in another angle, usually a more interesting one. Values are colors and shading.

There are things like composition which I would call a mastery but its something you can learn the entire time.

last_replies.com: I'm absolutely convinced that improving your handwriting is a fast track to improving your drawing. You've already got the shapes in your visual library, and forming sentences is trivial. You can just write your name over and over and over, if you want to be lazy. Or you can copy down a poem you like. Or if you want to be really fancy, you can do "The quick brown fox jumped over the lazy dog." or whatever. Or Lorem ipsum. And you can start with pencil and then ink over it. You'll get to practice using your entire arm which will feed directly into your line work. It will train your eye to see small imperfections in curves. When dealing with negative space, it's a lot easier to reason about the "anatomy" of letters than complicated silhouettes of organic objects, like the human face (e.g. the two faces that form a vase shown in every art textbook on the planet). Now... learn new typefaces. Heck, write your name in bubble letters and shade it like it's a balloon animal. Now you can practice shape *and* value. Most importantly, just draw.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6407108
> Wake up after full 8 hours sleep
> Stretch and lift for 20-30 mins, nothing exhausting, just enough to "feel it"
> Eat breakfast with cat
> Send out any packages from online store sales by short walk to post office
> Come home, Draw
> Lunch, stretch, play with cat again
> Resume draw until sun starts to set
> Take walk while there's still some light
> Watch a movie or show in personal collection (future drawing ideas sometimes come from watching stuff)
> Keep drawing, but at a slower pace while watching
> Finish movie and drawing for the day, play about an hour of video games or jerk off
> Look over drawing one last time before getting ready for bed to see what might need work next day
All this to keep physically and mentally fit.

>>6405551
I drew a quick 2 point perspective grid on your piece to show you how the main character isn't on the same plane as the dead bodies or background. It makes the perspective confusing and it makes the piece look a little 'off.' >>6406847 also rectified this by making him bigger and moving him closer to us.

By making the figure bigger the piece can be corrected w/o having to redraw the entire piece and then can move onto coloring. Also, by moving him closer to us and it really looks like he's leaving behind a trail of death and destruction for us to see so it would heavily improve the storytelling of your piece as well and making it more dynamic due to the contrast in his bigger size compared to the smaller bodies he passes by.

In the future I would recommend studying up on perspective more so that you can make sure that all of your stuff is on the same or similar planes, at least. Once you start to learn more you can use a rough perspective grid to plan out your compositions.

>>6408532
Artists study more than one influence. Steve Rude doesn't just copy Toth, there's Steranko, Kirby, Frazetta and stuff. Art is rarely made in a vacuum, and when it is your lack of input starts limiting you really fast.
When it comes to appeal there's really no getting out of studying other people. It's not that you're meant to copy their choices verbatim and become a dollar store version of the original, but use your studies to understand why they do things the way they do and use that to inform your decisions.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6408339
Appeal is subject to things like pop culture and trendsetters. All you can do is either chase mass appeal and copy the most current popular art, or chase your inner desires and appeal to yourself first and foremost. One will bring you riches, the other will bring you internal fulfillment. Sometimes what you personally like will overlap with what is popular, and that's kind of an ideal scenario.
Art online is like giving a stranger a free gift in the middle of a department store where everything is free. It better be a kickass gift if you expect them to care.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6400294
>to add, apprentices were accepted based on if they showed skill, so many must have been quite good already before entering.
Not necessarily true. Many were entered at an age young enough that they wouldn't've shown much skill at all. Andrea del Sarto was apprenticed at 7 years of age. He was a son of a tailor, and was apprenticed to a goldsmith because he liked to draw. It was more of a "looks like my son doesn't enjoy this thing that I do for a living, and enjoys artistic stuff, and I have enough sons that one of them will inherit the family business." kind of thing.
This was a financial agreement first and foremost: Parents still paid the master for their kids upkeep, but the master had to pay wages to their apprentices. And yes, this means that most apprentices were earning money from apprenticing from about 10 years of age.

>and the studio training included hands on projects and learning how to prepare things
Yes. Especially grinding pigments and preparing panels. Then learning to draw, by copying other artists or their masters. Then drawing from statuettes and casts, then from statues, then from live models. Then painting - usually the less important parts of their masters' paintings.

>they also learned how to design different objects and decorations in the meantime
You weren't usually allowed to design anything until your apprenticeship period was over, unless your master was *really* busy, like Neri di Bicci. You would've *worked* on those decorations though, applying your master's designs.

>there can't have been that much time spent for instructing into figure drawing in the same way that modern courses do.
There was quite a lot, usually apprentices drawing each other in various poses, etc. This served a dual purpose: To train them, and to create a library of drawings that could be used for parts of more finished work later. These collections were extremely valuable at the time, and often the most important item in a master's will.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6406910
7 is quite young for apprenticeship or learning how to draw. around the teenage years is more common, with some even being late teens. the first steps into getting into painting before a proper apprenticeship was often drawing from public frescoes and sculptures, and other artists were often present drawing as well, or had informal training under artist relatives outside of the guild system.
i think the tiered system of progression from casts to real sculptures and so on is an idea partly from later training method, simply due to sculptures being available for the public to see, and there's no reason why an apprentice would have to draw from a cast first if the studio has their own sculptures.
i didn't say that they worked on the decorations themselves for the master to use during their apprenticeship, but that it's something they learned. especially if they apprenticed under a goldsmith or carver in wood or stone which many of them did, or trained under someone with such a background. even if apprenticed under a painter, among the drawings they had access to copy would be supplemental designs.
i just mean this training is unlike modern courses that focus mostly on teaching how to draw figures, in that it is more encompassing and also more hands-on with the production process. it's also why so many came out as architects as well. in rare cases like taddeo zucchero's he was not even allowed to draw unless it was in his own time.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6406802
>most people when they want that they consume animation, or video games, not comics,
They consume that stuff as well. You're just talking about preference for medium, not the qualities of the medium itself.
>Anon, Bleach, and specially Dragon Ball Z/Super are 99.9% art, and 00.01% "story"
Dragonball's another fantastic example of using the medium to tell the story. It's a very compelling read, despite the story being very one-note, and that's because the author knew how to use art and story in tandem.
I'm saying the art is PART of the "story", or rather, it's the medium for telling it. You'd understand this if you ever made comics, or movies, or really any storytelling medium that blends other mediums to tell a story. It's not as simple as throwing some text or audio on an image, there's much more to it than that. Choosing what image, how you draw it, how you phrase the text, if you use text at all or a lot of it etc are all STORYTELLING choices that are not STORY choices. Do you understand? It's a fundamental part of making comics to tell a story with visuals, and it takes skill to do so.
To use another medium as an example to help clarify: moviemakers are not necessarily photographers, because shooting a movie uses multiple mediums to tell a story, while a photographer's primary (and perhaps only) goal is capture a single moment or a series of single moments, to show off a bunch of pretty pictures. They are fundamentally different, and a movie can succeed at telling a story with visuals and sound and movement while not having very many pretty pictures at all, or not having very good writing or whatever.

Medibang is good, very conservative with its resource usage, and it has some killer features (specifically the one and eight bit drawing modes, screentone painting, built in tools for making comics) but the ads are annoying and you can't get rid of them, or use the actually useful file manager and some other built in app features unless you pay for a stupid subscription bundle with stuff you probably will never need. Pirate if at all possible.
Artflow is better, though more resource hungry. The brush engine is more versatile and it has the absolute best UI I've ever seen. It also only requires a single, very cheap one time purchase to use it forever. The only major drawback is that it saves files in its own format instead of commonly used ones like .PSD or .ORA, so exporting documents en masse will be a painful, PAINFUL ordeal if, like me, you used it for literal years before finding out that this was the case when you attempt to clear some space by offloading the files.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
The book could be condensed to just a few pages. The majority of the text is about the pscyhology of seeing/drawing, I guess? It's not that interesting and it doesn't really help you, unless you're teaching or trying to source/formulate an argument.

Here's the main points:

1.) Draw what you see. This is easier said than done, but it's the hard truth. The head isn't a circle, so don't draw it that way. We're not doing smiley faces unless we're illustrators and deliberately want that.

2.) Reset your eyes. Your brain and eyes are constantly trying to deceive you. So don't let them. Flip the page, take a break, whatever.

3.) You can learn to draw. It's an acquired skill. HOWEVER, interest and ability seem to be strongly correlated. Interest is likely innate/nature -- therefore making talent seem like a God-given trait. The longer you work, the more progress you will see. Just like lifting weights or doing math. If you can persevere, you can learn art. But you may not have an inherent interest in shapes and color, just as I have no interest in moving iron and dating.

4.) No rules, only tools. Just draw.

>>6402308
honestly i have always had a better time simply being thrown into the thick of it and doing rather than taking baby steps.
i found the book -too- slow, too. it goes way too long into personal experiences of the author with extremely boring stories and.supposed "science".
it also rejects the idea of just needing a drawing implement and paper and expects you to create a "frame" using a clear glass panel instead of just using your hands and pencil to frame and sight measure.
i honestly believe a beginner life drawing class from a local community college or really anything online would benefit far more than this - to be frank - book of psychobabble quackery.
